metadata.title: Discovering Patterns in Data with Exploratory Data Analysis | by Jocelyn Lutes | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Discovering Patterns in Data with Exploratory Data Analysis
metadata.description: First described in 1977 by John W. Tukey, Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) refers to the process of exploring data in order to understand relationships between variables, detect anomalies, and…

all_paragraphs: First described in 1977 by John W. Tukey, Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) refers to the process of exploring data in order to understand relationships between variables, detect anomalies, and understand if variables satisfy assumptions for statistical inference [1]. EDA can be a very powerful tool for discovering patterns in data and prompting the development of new research questions. In this post, I will describe how I used EDA to uncover trends in a dataset and how these trends helped me formulate and answer a research question.

This project was completed as part of General Assembly’s Data Science Immersive Bootcamp. The objective of this project was to use EDA to uncover trends in SAT and ACT data in order to make recommendations for a data science problem. For this project, I received six datasets that provided SAT and ACT data by state for the years 2017, 2018, and 2019. Variables in the dataset included average scores and average participation rates by state. To prepare for EDA, I cleaned the data and merged all six datasets into a single Pandas data frame of 51 rows and 23 columns . A partial header of the data frame is shown below.

As part of my EDA, I create several figures to investigate trends in participation rates on the SAT and ACT. I was most interested in how SAT and ACT participation rates varied over time and by geographic location.

In order to explore trends in participation rates over time, I used Seaborn and Matplotlib to create box plots for each test and year. Comparing the distributions in participation rates allowed me to understand not only how median participation changed over time, but also how the variance of the distribution changed.
From the above plot, I noticed an increasing trend in median SAT participation from 2017 to 2019.

The above box plots began to illustrate a national trend in ACT and SAT participation rates from 2017 to 2019. It appeared that more states began to increase participation in the SAT, while participation in the ACT decreased.

As I was exploring the data, I also used Plotly to create choropleth maps of SAT and ACT participation rates by state. As shown below, these plots illustrated that, in 2017, with the exception of Michigan and Indiana, SAT participation was highest in coastal states, while ACT participation dominated in the central states.

Given the temporal trends in participation rates that I had uncovered using box plots and the geographical difference in participation that was illustrated with the choropleth maps, a research question was formed. Because most Midwestern states demonstrated low SAT participation rates at baseline (2017), I decided to explore if the Midwest also experienced an overall increase in median SAT participation from 2017 to 2019.

To begin, I created a Pandas data frame that only contained data for the Midwestern states (Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin). From there, I was able to create a box plot using Seaborn and Matplotlib to look at the distribution of SAT participation from 2017 to 2019. As shown in the figure below, although variance in participation rates increased from 2017 to 2019, the median SAT participation rate remained similar over the three year span. Further exploration of the data revealed that the increased variance from 2017 to 2018 was largely due to increased SAT participation in Illinois and Ohio.

This project demonstrated the power of EDA at uncovering trends in data that can later be used to generate a research question. Using simple plots created with Matplotlib, Seaborn, and Plotly, I was able to discover an increasing trend in SAT participation from 2017 to 2019 and a geographic preference for the ACT in Midwestern states at baseline (2017). Combined, these insights inspired me to investigate if the increasing trend in SAT participation was also seen in the Midwestern states. With just six simple graphs (of only two types), I was able to identify a research question and seek an answer. Imagine what insights you can discover with EDA!
